keyTakeAways: The new White House ballroom, costing $250 million, is being funded through a mix of personal contributions from Donald Trump and anonymous corporate donations, including from major tech and defense firms.
YouTube is confirmed as a donor, having paid $22 million as part of a legal settlement with Trump over the Capitol riot account suspension.

The White House claims no taxpayer costs, and that the ballroom will be used by future administrations, but legal experts fear it may constitute a 'pay-to-play' scheme where access to the White House is exchanged for financial contributions.

A dinner event on 15 October included executives from Blackstone, OpenAI, Microsoft, Coinbase, Palantir, Lockheed Martin, Amazon, and Google, as well as Woody Johnson and the Glazer family, signaling deep corporate involvement.
Donors may receive recognition, such as names etched into the ballroom, raising concerns about transparency and potential political favoritism.

Former ethics lawyer Richard Painter warns that the project could amount to an ethics nightmare, citing historical precedents like Bill Clinton's Lincoln Bedroom stays and Trump's past attempts to solicit corporate sponsorship for events.
The ballroom's capacity has been updated from 650 to 999, suggesting a significant expansion to accommodate larger events and potentially more influential guests.
The Trust for the National Mall is handling the donations, a non-profit organization that also works with the National Park Service and funds White House-related projects.
Trump stated that he personally would take any donation of $25 million, and that many attendees were 'really, really generous'.

summaryOfNewsArticle: The construction of President Donald Trump's new $250 million White House ballroom has sparked ethical controversy, with questions over whether corporate donors—such as Blackstone, Microsoft, Amazon, Google, and others—are funding the project in exchange for access to the administration. Although the White House claims the renovation will not cost taxpayers and will be used by future administrations, legal experts like Richard Painter warn it may constitute a 'pay-to-play' scheme, reminiscent of past abuses like Bill Clinton’s Lincoln Bedroom stays. A dinner on October 15 included senior executives from major companies and sports owners, with YouTube contributing $22 million from a legal settlement tied to the January 6 Capitol riot. Donors may receive public recognition, such as names etched into the ballroom, raising transparency concerns. While the White House insists there is nothing inappropriate, the scale and nature of the funding model have ignited debate about the ethics of political influence and access.
title: Who is paying for Donald Trump's new White House ballroom?
